title: Netflix to introduce official age classifications on all its films and shows
text:
Murray Perkins, the BBFC’s policy director, said: "It's vital that families are given the information and guidance that they need - and want - so they can choose well, and so they can avoid content that might upset them.”

Research for the BBFC of 3,000 parents and children found that 32 per cent of teenager saw distressing content every week, with one in 20 saying they felt it affected their mental health.

With children increasingly spurning traditional broadcasters for digital alternatives, the BBFC is in talks with Amazon Prime, Sky Store and other video streaming services to extend the classification system to their platforms.

The logos have had to be redesigned because the current ones carry a waterprint of the BBFC initials in the background and cannot be seen clearly in a digital format. The design change even required an amendment to the law to permit it.

About 70 per cent of Netflix's films and shows have age classifications which will now have the newly-designed logos clearly displayed for parents and children.

Mr Perkins added: "Parents tell us how tough it can be to navigate the online world safely, and we're here to help with that.

"We have been rating content for over 100 years, so we have a lot of experience to draw from and as the landscape of viewing content changes, so do we.

"We do large scale research every four to five years to understand what matters and how attitudes are changing, most especially for children and families.

"We’re proud to be launching digital symbols for a digital audience, to help them get the information they need so they can view what's right for them."
description: Netflix is for the first time to carry official sex and violence film classifications by Britain’s chief censor as research shows a third of teenagers see content every week that upsets them.
